posts.cooked:
With my current phone getting old I‚Äôm considering replacing it with a phone running /e/OS or GrapheneOS. What I‚Äôm not sure about, though, is how the experience using Signal will be on those platforms.

I‚Äôd be happy if some people could share their experience with using Signal on these platforms and if they‚Äôve done anything special to make sure that e.g. notifications work properly.

Cheers!
I have used both Signal and Molly on DivestOS and AXP.OS-slim without FCM. Notifications haven‚Äôt been a problem.

TeeJay82:

running /e/OS or GrapheneOS

I don‚Äôt have any experience with /e/OS, but I‚Äôve read that its security is inferior to others. The operating systems I see most recommended are GrapheneOS and CalyxOS. I also think that iodeOS should be pretty good.

CueHD:

I‚Äôve read that its security is inferior to others.

Compared to what? If it‚Äôs comparable to stock Android it‚Äôs good enough for me.

CueHD:

I‚Äôve read that its security is inferior to others.

Exactly

kuketz-blog.de

/e/: Datenschutzfreundlich bedeutet nicht zwangsl√§ufig sicher ‚Äì Custom-ROMs...

/e/ punktet beim Datenschutz, aber hinsichtlich der Sicherheit bestehen erhebliche Bedenken.

Not only the delayed provision of security updates (6 weeks and more) is worth mentioning, but above all the slow update of WebView components. If no updates are provided here for more than 6 months, one can speak of a significant security risk. [translated by Firefox]

TeeJay82:

I‚Äôm considering replacing it with a phone running /e/OS or GrapheneOS.

If you can‚Äô I‚Äôd recommend buying Pixel and choosing GOS. In addition to the to the source I linked above, there‚Äôs also interesting comparison.

eylenburg.github.io

Comparison of Android-based Operating Systems

Comparison of Android-based Operating Systems

/e/ doesn‚Äôt compare favorably compared to GOS. Even if you don‚Äôt care about GOS hardening, there‚Äôs also problem with very slow security updates.

Security update speed (AOSP subset of ASB) - 1-2 months, sometimes longer
Full patches on fully supported devices - Many months to over a year
Webview update speed - Several weeks/months

Anyway, I‚Äôve been using GOS for years now (with GPlay Services) and everything works fine. Had problem with notifications once buy GPlay compatibility layer update fixed this and no problem since.

link_counts.title: /e/: Datenschutzfreundlich bedeutet nicht zwangsl√§ufig sicher ‚Äì Custom-ROMs Teil6 ‚Ä¢ Kuketz IT-Security Blog

posts.cooked:
TeeJay82:

If it‚Äôs comparable to stock Android it‚Äôs good enough for me.

It depends on what you‚Äôre looking for. One security decision that is interior to stock Android is their choice to use publicly available test keys for signing. This would allow a malicious package to pass any verified boot checks even though it shouldn‚Äôt.

If you‚Äôre purchasing a newer phone, one that is compatible with GrapheneOS or CalyxOS would be better. If you are restoring an old phone, I‚Äôve found AXP.OS to work well.

DirkPitt1:

Exactly

TeeJay82:

I‚Äôm considering replacing it with a phone running /e/OS or GrapheneOS.

If you can‚Äô I‚Äôd recommend buying Pixel and choosing GOS. In addition to the to the source I linked above, there‚Äôs also interesting comparison.

Ah, I see that this guy works as a pen tester and is using GrapheneOS by conviction . And good to know. Although, to be fair: my current phone is a Motorola approaching its 4th anniversary of being EOL.

DirkPitt1:

Anyway, I‚Äôve been using GOS for years now (with GPlay Services) and everything works fine. Had problem with notifications once buy GPlay compatibility layer update fixed this and no problem since.

Is this the sandboxed GPlay thing that I‚Äôve read about?

Do you happen to know for how long GrapheneOS is committed to providing updates for a given phone model? One thing that I like a lot about Fairphone is, that besides their proposition of, well, being fair, they are using an IOT SOC which means that they can get security updates for it for a long time. They also have replacable batteries. This means that I could potentially get a lot of mileage out of my purchase. And Fairphone collaborate with Murena to sell /e/OS preinstalled!

posts.name: (he/him)
posts.cooked: I‚Äôve been interchangeably using Signal and Molly on CalyxOS, works fine. very rarely a notification gets delivered with a few minutes delay (even though I use microG with GCM), but nothing terrible.

TeeJay82:

Do you happen to know for how long GrapheneOS is committed to providing updates for a given phone model?

when official updates from Google stop for Pixel, so do updates for GrapheneOS.

TeeJay82:

One thing that I like a lot about Fairphone is, that besides their proposition of, well, being fair, they are using an IOT SOC which means that they can get security updates for it for a long time. They also have replacable batteries.

I am intrigued by Fairphone and Shiftphone too. I recently read somewhere that using an IoT SOC might be backfiring as they weren‚Äôt designed to handle the type of use a smartphone will put on them. I like that they still have removable storage.

chrononaut:

when official updates from Google stop for Pixel, so do updates for GrapheneOS.

Not exactly. GrapheneOS does backport security updates if they can. Official support from Google for Pixels below 6 have ended, but GrapheneOS and CalyxOS still support them. They do not receive firmware nor driver updates though.

GrapheneOS

GrapheneOS Frequently Asked Questions

Answers to frequently asked questions about GrapheneOS.

calyxos.org

Device Support

üôã Check out device support timelines and preferences below!

AXP.OS goes back a bit older.

axpos.org

Devices

Select your vendor and model from the left menu If you miss a device you can request it here.

TeeJay82:

Is this the sandboxed GPlay thing that I‚Äôve read about?

Yes.

TeeJay82:

Do you happen to know for how long GrapheneOS is committed to providing updates for a given phone model?

Full support is provided as long as Google supports their phones. For newer Pixels (from 8 I think) it‚Äôs 7 years since their release, for older it was 5. After that time, you still get extended support with AOSP security patches backported when it‚Äôs possible but not firmware updates.

How long is the extended support period? The oldest extended support device right now is Pixel 4, so it looks like about 3 years, according to this Google Pixel | endoflife.date

posts.name: Bme13
posts.cooked: I used Signal on my Samsung S9 running /e/OS for several years. Notifications worked quite well. Perhaps the only thing I‚Äôve changed was disabling battery optimization.

posts.name: Whatnoww
posts.cooked: GrapheneOS is pretty much king on Pixel 8 and later. Signal works just as well (or as poorly) as stock without websocket.

Hmm, having looked at it a bit more:

  • /e/ have forums, where criticism on slow updates also has been discussed. Looks like they had some trouble with dependencies in 2023‚Ä¶?
  • What I like is that Murena offer Murena cloud, which would be great for syncing a couple of things, amongst which my contacts. I‚Äôm not yet sure if something equivalent is available for GrapheneOS. I don‚Äôt really want to be running my own NextCloud yet.

Btw, I hope that this isn‚Äôt too much of a tangent for these subforums, but I‚Äôd say that Signal users ought to be interested in this sort of thing .

You could signup for a Murena cloud account even if you don‚Äôt use /e/. You can also install their ‚ÄúApp Lounge‚Äù and use their apps. There is no need to install /e/ as the operating system if all you want is their cloud service.

posts.name: Bme13
posts.cooked: The think I like about /e/ is that they try to provide a complete system, so not only the device os. I do appreciate their effort in trying to create a google free environment. It is not all perfect though. Besides the slow updates they had quite a big outage with their cloud service a while ago that lasted way too long (think a couple of weeks). I like to give /e/ credits for their effort though, but that being said my Samsung s9 replacement is a second hand Pixel so at least I have the option to switch to GrapheneOS.

They also had an issue where users started seeing other users photos and files because their cloud solution isn‚Äôt end to end encrypted and something was messed up where you would just see other people‚Äôs files or photos

Overall I‚Äôd say grapheneos but this is a good little piece about the choice you have

I did not know about the Pixel‚Äôs security features compared to other vendors, thanks!

Right now I can get a Pixel 8 at a reasonable price. I think that I‚Äôll just get one and run it stock for a while and install GrapheneOS later, preferably once Signal cloud back-ups are available.

Should have me set for the next 5 years in terms of updates, regardless of what I decide to do.
Are you unable to use local backups?
Hm, no. But I‚Äôm just lazy .
